channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Gaza ceasefire comes into effect
item.description: A ceasefire between Israel and the Hamas movement which governs Gaza comes into effect after a week of violence and nearly 160 deaths.

item.title: PM 'sad' women bishops rejected
item.description: David Cameron says he is "very sad" that the Church of England's general synod has rejected the introduction of women bishops.

item.title: Chelsea name Benitez interim boss
item.description: Chelsea appoint former Liverpool boss Rafael Benitez as interim manager until the end of the season.

item.title: Inmate jailed for Whiting attack
item.description: A prisoner who stabbed child killer Roy Whiting at Wakefield jail says he did it because of his notoriety, as he is sentenced for the attack.

item.title: Week-old boy killed by pet dog
item.description: A week-old boy dies after being bitten by his family's pet dog, with his parents saying there are "no words to describe the loss".

item.title: Lords court defeats for ministers
item.description: The government is defeated over plans to allow ministers to order secret court hearings to hear evidence in cases relating to national security.

item.title: Whole life prison terms upheld
item.description: The Court of Appeal upholds the principle of whole life sentences for the most dangerous of offenders, saying it does not breach human rights.

item.title: Boys arrested over mugging death
item.description: Two teenagers are arrested following the death of an 85-year-old woman who was mugged in an alleyway in west London.

item.title: UK public sector borrowing rises
item.description: The government borrowed a worse-than-expected Â£8.6bn in October, reducing the chances the UK will hit its deficit reduction target, figures show.

item.title: Church institute liable for abuse
item.description: A Catholic teaching institute is ruled liable for alleged physical and sexual abuse at a former boys' school in East Yorkshire.

item.title: Students march in London protest
item.description: Thousands of students have marched through London to protest against the rising costs of university and further education.

item.title: Roads 'impassable' after flooding
item.description: Heavy rain leads to flooding with motorists and residents needing rescue from waterlogged roads and homes in south-west England.

item.title: Woman finds snake on toilet seat
item.description: An elderly couple are left "shocked" after finding a python wrapped round a toilet seat at their home in Paisley.

item.title: Early death link to muscle power
item.description: How muscular you are as a teenager may predict how long you might live, at least if you are a man, findings suggest.

item.title: No Greek deal 'threatens euro'
item.description: The failure of the eurozone to reach a deal to give Greece its latest bailout payment threatens the whole of the bloc, European leaders say.

item.title: Hostess gets 'flood of enquiries'
item.description: Hostess Brands, the company that makes Twinkies, has received a "flood of enquiries" about buying some of its brands, according to its lawyer.

item.title: Cameron tackled over Middle East
item.description: Troubles in the Middle East lead the subjects covered at David Cameron's first Prime Minister's Questions since the parliamentary recess.

item.title: Work tests 'lack disabled access'
item.description: The firm carrying out fitness-for-work assessments for the government lacks disabled access at almost a quarter of its premises, MPs have heard.

item.title: Warning over liver disease rates
item.description: Drinking and obesity levels mean England is one of Europe's few countries still seeing a rise in liver disease deaths, the chief medical officer warns.

item.title: No more claims for PIP patients
item.description: Owners of Harley Medical Group financially restructures meaning patients can no longer claim compensation for faulty PIP breast implants.

item.title: Gangs abuse 'thousands of young'
item.description: Thousands of children are sexually abused by gangs and groups in England each year, according to the first in-depth report into the scale of the problem.

item.title: Fall in school IT tests problems
item.description: There has been a reduction in problems with school computer tests, the Stormont Education Committee hears.

item.title: Kickstarter sued over 3D printers
item.description: Kickstarter has been sued over claims that a 3D printer marketed through its site infringes a patent owned by one of the sector's pioneers.

item.title: Google attacks net treaty talks
item.description: Google calls on web users to sign a petition raising concerns that a forthcoming UN conference poses a risk to a "free and open internet".

item.title: Dwarf planet Makemake laid bare
item.description: Astronomers make use of a chance event to get a look at the Makemake, one of five "dwarf planets" that also include former favoured planet Pluto.

item.title: UN warning as emissions gap grows
item.description: A report by the UN says global attempts to curb emissions of CO2 are falling well short of what is needed to stem dangerous climate change.

item.title: Winslet and Barlow accept honours
item.description: Oscar-winning actress Kate Winslet and Take That singer Gary Barlow are among stars honoured by The Queen at Buckingham Palace.

item.title: Rothko repair 'to take 18 months'
item.description: Black on Maroon, the Mark Rothko painting defaced at London's Tate Modern in October, could take up to 18 months to repair, the BBC understands.

item.title: Why feeling guilty may make you a better boss
item.description: Recent research suggests that people who feel guilty for trivial transgressions might make better leaders.

item.title: Five reasons to still use a typewriter
item.description: Today marks the end of an era as the last typewriter built in the UK rolls off the production line at Brother's north Wales factory. But who still uses them and why?

item.title: Drogba wants loan move from China
item.description: Former Chelsea striker Didier Drogba wants to leave Shanghai Shenhua on loan, despite being outside the transfer window.

item.title: Last SPOTY tickets to go on sale
item.description: Remaining tickets for BBC Sports Personality of the Year 2012 to go on sale on Thursday 22 November at 09:00 GMT.

item.title: Dettori banned on medical grounds
item.description: Frankie Dettori is banned from riding in France 'on medical grounds' pending a hearing into his failed drugs test.

item.title: Watmore to build on impressive England debut
item.description: Jo Watmore is one of several exciting talents England Women will unleash on New Zealand in their forthcoming Test series

item.title: Medals for men who tackled gunman
item.description: Two men who wrestled a gunman to the floor on board a nuclear submarine receive the George Medal for bravery from the Queen.

item.title: Murder charge over 1990 boy death
item.description: A man is charged with murdering a teenage boy whose body was found in Sunderland 22 years ago.

item.title: Man guilty of murdering soldier
item.description: A man is convicted for a second time of murdering a decorated Scottish soldier in Renfrewshire.

item.title: Housing repairs director resigns
item.description: One of Edinburgh City Council's senior directors, who was suspended as part of an investigation into the authority's property repairs service, resigns.

item.title: All health trusts miss A&E target
item.description: All Northern Ireland's A&E departments could be performing a lot better when it comes to treating patients within four hours, according to a new report.

item.title: Stormont post 'led to flashbacks'
item.description: Ann Travers tells a Stormont committee she has suffered constant flashbacks after Sinn Fein appointed a woman convicted of her sister's murder as a special adviser to one of its ministers.

item.title: Wales backing for women bishops
item.description: The Archbishop of Wales says he hopes to be able to ordain women bishops before very long, as the Church of England votes against the idea.

item.title: Murder arrests after baby death
item.description: Two people are arrested on suspicion of murdering a one-month-old baby girl in Cwmbran.

item.title: Congo rebels threaten new advance
item.description: Rebels in DR Congo threaten to advance to the capital, Kinshasa, after capturing the eastern city of Goma as regional leaders hold crisis talks.

item.title: French citizen kidnapped in Mali
item.description: France says a French citizen has been kidnapped in south-west Mali, outside the part of the country now controlled by Islamists.

item.title: Mumbai attacks gunman executed
item.description: Mohammad Ajmal Amir Qasab, the sole surviving gunman from the 2008 Mumbai attacks, is executed in prison.

item.title: Dismay over new Afghan executions
item.description: Human rights groups criticise Afghanistan for hanging 14 people in two days after a virtual moratorium on executions for years.

item.title: Fillon demands UMP ballot recount
item.description: French ex-PM Francois Fillon, narrowly defeated in the leadership ballot for France's opposition conservative party, demands a recount

item.title: Nato mulls Turkey's missile plea
item.description: Nato says it is considering a request by Turkey to deploy Patriot anti-missile systems to protect its border with conflict-torn Syria.

item.title: US and Mexico agree water deal
item.description: Mexico and the US sign a new agreement on sharing and managing the Colorado River, the source of water for millions of people in the two countries.

item.title: Bolivia shuts down for census day
item.description: Bolivia imposes a curfew and orders all its citizens to go back home and wait to be counted in the first census there in 11 years.

item.title: Bahrain medics get jail sentences
item.description: A court in Bahrain sentences 23 medics to three months in jail for their alleged roles in last year's anti-government uprisings, officials say.

item.title: Ten killed in Yemen plane crash
item.description: A Yemeni military plane has crashed in the capital, Sanaa, killing all 10 people on board, officials say.

item.title: US hits the road for Thanksgiving
item.description: An estimated 43 million Americans hit the road on the eve of Thanksgiving, amid bad weather and transport union action.

item.title: No last-gasp Twinkie talks deal
item.description: Last-ditch efforts break down aimed at ending a labour dispute threatening the future of Twinkies, one of the best-known US snack food brands.

item.title: Day in pictures: 21 November 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 21 November

item.title: In pictures: Israel-Gaza violence
item.description: Israeli strikes continued into a seventh day

item.title: In pictures: Violence in Gaza and Israel
item.description: Images from the Gaza and Israel

item.title: Week in pictures: 10-16 November 2012
item.description: News photos from around the world

item.title: In pictures: Olly Moss's alternative film posters
item.description: Alternative film posters by artist Olly Moss

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 November 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 20 November

item.title: In pictures: Solar-powered floating schools
item.description: Solar-powered floating schools in Bangladesh

item.title: In pictures: Israeli air strikes
item.description: Images from the Palestinian territory of Gaza

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron has called on Israeli and Palestinian leaders to display "courageous leadership" on ending the conflict that has seen rocket attacks on southern Israel and airstrikes in Gaza.

item.title: VIDEO: Take That! Barlow gets royal honour
item.description: Kate Winslet, Gary Barlow and Darren Clarke add a touch of stardust to Buckingham Places as they accept honours from the Queen.

item.title: VIDEO: Heavy rainfall causes flooding
item.description: Heavy rain causes flooding and travel problems across the west of England.

item.title: VIDEO: Week-old boy killed by pet dog
item.description: A week-old boy has died after being bitten by his family's pet dog in Shropshire.

item.title: VIDEO: Cameron on Cyril Smith abuse claim
item.description: The prime minister said Greater Manchester Police had opened an investigation into allegations "from 1974 onwards" around the former MP Cyril Smith.

item.title: VIDEO: The specially modified 'pregnant plane'
item.description: Dallas Campbell discovers how the different sections of a jumbo jet come together from around the world to be assembled in the USA.

item.title: VIDEO: Bendy, plastic electronics on show
item.description: BBC News talks to three companies working in the field of plastic, printable electronics, at the 2012 Plastics Show held in Birmingham.

item.title: VIDEO: New Zealand volcano erupts
item.description: A volcano has erupted on New Zealand's North Island, sending a column of ash high into the atmosphere.

item.title: VIDEO: Royal underwear sells at auction
item.description: Queen Victoria's linen bloomers and items belonging to Princess Diana have sold among 150 lots of Royal memorabilia in Essex.

item.title: History's most extraordinary blind leader?
item.description: Who was the blind leader that stole these horses?

item.title: Life after Ireland's bailout
item.description: Irish potato-seller laments ongoing crisis

item.title: Can good design save the economy?
item.description: Can good design save the economy, asks Andrew Marr

item.title: VIDEO: Sir Peter Blake: Rock Paper Scissors
item.description: Sgt Pepper artist's London retrospective

item.title: Can El Salvador's gang truce last?
item.description: Meet the gang chiefs trying to halt El Salvador's killings

item.title: Unveiled Syrian Facebook post stirs women's rights debate
item.description: How a Syrian woman's Facebook post sparked online furore

item.title: How technology opens the door for personalised pricing
item.description: How online retailers can set prices just for you

item.title: England must bounce back in style - Onions
item.description: England must bounce back in style in second Test

item.title: China diary: Electronics Street
item.description: The sheer naked capitalism of Shenzhen's Electronics Street
